title: Salivary and serum leptin levels in oral lichen planus patients. A case-control study
abstract: BackgroundLichen planus (LP) is a chronic inflammatory disease. Oral lichen planus (OLP) is a chronic inflammatory disease that affects the oral mucosa. Different clinical types of oral lichen planus can be diagnosed based on clinical presentation and histopathological features.AimThe present study aimed to assess the potential of salivary and serum leptin in the diagnosis of OLP.Materials & MethodsThe study was conducted on 78 cases (i.e., 39 cases per group) with OLP. The subjects were systematically free. Salivary and serum leptin concentrations from patients exhibiting a classic OLP and from healthy controls were assessed.ResultsSalivary and serum leptin levels are higher in the OLP group. The participants in the study are older than those in the control group; therefore, the age difference between the two groups does not affect the study’s results.ConclusionSalivary and serum leptin levels in OLP patients were higher than in healthy control subjects, suggesting a possible role in the process of OLP pathogenesis.

title: The remineralizing ability of self-assembling peptide P11-4, 2% arginine enriched sodium fluoride and functionalized tri calcium phosphate fluoride varnishes in treatment of white spot lesions – a randomized controlled trial
abstract: BackgroundWhite spot lesions (WSLs) is a caries lesion distinguished by white opacity due to subsurface enamel demineralization. These lesions resulting from a disparity between detrimental and protective factors and can continue to demineralize if untreated. Early diagnosis and remineralization can reverse WSLs, supporting minimally invasive dental care.AimTo compare and assess the color of WSLs through spectrophotometer after application of Self-assembling peptide P11-4, 2% Arginine Enriched Sodium Fluoride varnish and Functionalized Tri Calcium Phosphate Fluoride varnish.MethodsThis randomized controlled triple-blind clinical trial enrolled pediatric participants (ages 8–12 years) presenting with moderate caries risk as defined by CAMBRA (Caries Management By Risk Assessment) criteria, with visible white spot lesions (WSLs) on the labial surfaces of maxillary permanent anterior teeth, classified as ICDAS scores 1 or 2. A total of 39 WSLs were incorporated into the study and randomly allocated into one of the three groups 13/each. Group I: Self-assembling peptide P11-4 varnish (study group), Group II: Arginine-enriched Sodium Fluoride varnish (study group) and Group III: Tri Calcium Phosphate Fluoride varnish (positive control group). The color change ΔE of each WSL was quantified using a spectrophotometer at the baseline. Dimensions of WSLs were assessed by digital photography, remineralizing agents were applied then patients were recalled for further applications after 3 and 6 months and for WSLs assessment after 3, 6 and 9 months.ResultsAll groups demonstrated progressive color improvement over time. At 3 months, Group I showed the least improvement (ΔE = 16.39 ± 3.04), followed by Group III (14.80 ± 3.11) and Group II (14.06 ± 4.46). By 9 months, Group II achieved (ΔE = 9.37 ± 3.79), and Group III (9.15 ± 2.74) surpassing Group I (12.21 ± 3.03). so both Group II and III ultimately outperformed Group I in color correction by the study’s end. Group II achieved significantly greater WSL reduction (14.98 ± 7.55%) compared to both Group I (27.93 ± 8.98%) and Group III (22.32 ± 8.61%), with no significant difference observed between Groups I and III.ConclusionsAlthough all the three tested materials demonstrated an enhancement in the color and dimension of WSLs, 2% of Arginine Enriched Sodium Fluoride showed the best results followed by Functionalized Tri Calcium Phosphate Fluoride varnish, while self-assembling peptide P11-4 showed the lowest results.

title: Clinical and radiographic outcomes after pulpotomies using mineral trioxide aggregate mixed with distilled water or 2.25% sodium hypochlorite gel: a randomized controlled clinical trial
abstract: ObjectivesSodium hypochlorite (NaOCl) gel is an effective additive for white mineral trioxide aggregate (WMTA) that enhances its chemical and physical characteristics and significantly reduces setting time while maintaining biocompatibility. The study sought to compare the outcomes of pulpotomies performed in primary teeth using WMTA mixed with 2.25% NaOCl gel or WMTA mixed with distilled water (DW).Materials and methodsIt was a randomized, triple-blinded, split-mouth, controlled clinical trial. Forty primary second molars from cooperative children aged 5–10 who required pulpotomy were randomly assigned to the control group—WMTA  + DW or experimental group—WMTA + NaOCl gel for clinical and radiographic assessments at 3, 6, and 12 months of follow-up. The clinical evaluation involved checking for spontaneous pain, pain on percussion, tooth mobility, abscesses, sinus tracts, and the exfoliation of the treated tooth. The periapical radiographic evaluation identified whether there was furcal radiolucency, internal or external root resorption, and widening of the periodontal ligament. Canal obliteration was not considered a failure.ResultsThe WMTA + NaOCl gel group showed a 90% and 95% clinical and radiographical success rate, respectively, at 3, 6, and 12 months of follow-up. In the control group, the clinical success rate was 90% after 3, 6, and 12 months, whereas the radiographical success rate was 100% at 3 months and decreased to 95% after 6 and to 85% after 12 months. No statistically significant difference was detected between the two groups (p> 0.05).ConclusionsThe present research validated WMTA + NaOCl gel as a potentially effective material for pulpotomy in primary molars.

title: Enhanced anti-influenza virus activity of saliva following toothbrushing
abstract: ObjectiveInfluenza, a respiratory infection caused by the influenza virus, has been associated with good oral hygiene, which correlates with a reduced incidence of the disease. Saliva possesses inherent antiviral properties against the influenza virus. However, the relationship between toothbrushing, a common oral hygiene practice, and the antiviral activity of saliva remains poorly understood. This study aimed to evaluate the effect of toothbrushing on the anti-influenza virus activity of saliva.Materials and methodsSixteen adults without oral disease participated in this open-label, single-arm study. Resting saliva and mouth-rinsed water samples were collected before toothbrushing. Participants then brushed their teeth with a toothbrush and toothpaste for five minutes, after which additional saliva and mouth-rinsed water samples were collected at five minutes and one-hour post-brushing. The total bacterial amount in the mouth-rinsed water was measured by qPCR. The anti-influenza virus activity of saliva was determined using the TCID₅₀ method.ResultsSaliva’s anti-influenza virus activity increased significantly five minutes after toothbrushing compared to pre-brushing levels, but no significant difference was observed at 1 h, as follows [Δlog, median (min-max)]: Before brushing: 0.625 (−0.25–1.75), at 5 min: 1.25 (0.5–2), and at 1 h: 0.75 (0.5–2). A correlation analysis between total bacterial amount and antiviral activity revealed a negative correlation.ConclusionsImproving the oral environment through toothbrushing enhances salivary antiviral activity. Maintaining oral hygiene may help prevent influenza virus infection.

title: Virtual reality in restorative dentistry: a bibliometric analysis of research trends
abstract: BackgroundVirtual reality (VR) technologies are increasingly being adopted in dental education, particularly in restorative dentistry, due to their capacity to simulate realistic clinical scenarios and enhance student learning. However, despite the growing interest, the overall research landscape in this field remains unclear. This study aimed to conduct a bibliometric analysis to evaluate the most influential research contributions, publication trends, and collaborative patterns related to VR in restorative dentistry.MethodsAn advanced search of the Web of Science Core Collection (WoS-CC) database was performed on 29th October 2024 using a combination of keywords and Medical Subject Headings (MeSH) terms relevant to VR and restorative dentistry. Only original research and review articles in English were included. Bibliometric parameters such as citation metrics, authorship, institutional affiliations, countries of origin, and keywords were extracted and analyzed using Bibliometrix (R) and VOSviewer software.ResultsOut of 434 retrieved records, 62 articles met the inclusion criteria. A marked increase in publications was observed after 2019, with the USA, UK, and Netherlands emerging as the leading contributors. The most cited article received 73 citations, focusing on haptic simulators for motor skill acquisition. TheJournal of Dental Education, theEuropean Journal of Dental Education, andBMC Medical Educationwere among the most prolific journals. Despite global contributions, the analysis revealed limited interdisciplinary and international collaboration.ConclusionThis bibliometric study highlights the increasing research activity surrounding VR in restorative dentistry and its potential to transform dental education. While considerable progress has been made, further high-quality research and broader collaborative efforts are necessary to address existing gaps and fully harness the capabilities of VR and related immersive technologies in dental education.

title: Performance of nitric acid and mineral enriched system versus phosphoric acid and universal adhesive in cervical carious lesions: a randomized clinical trial
abstract: ObjectiveTo evaluate the clinical performance of nitric acid associated with a mineral-enriched adhesive system compared to the conventional approach of phosphoric acid and a universal adhesive in cervical carious lesion restorations.Materials and methodsTwenty-six individuals with 44 cervical anterior carious lesions were randomized into two equal parallel groups. The intervention group received a nitric acid etch(Clean and Boost dentin enamel cleanser, Vista Apex, USA)in conjunction with a mineral-enriched adhesive and a flowable composite liner(RE-GEN, Vista Apex, USA). Control group treated with phosphoric acid(Scotchbond Universal Etchant, 3 M ESPE), a universal adhesive(Single Bond Universal Adhesive, 3 M ESPE), and a standard liner(Filtek Supreme, 3 M ESPE). All cavities were restored using nanohybrid resin composite(Filtek Z350XT, 3 M ESPE). Postoperative sensitivity was assessed both qualitatively, using the modified USPHS criteria, and quantitatively, using a visual analog scale (VAS), as the primary outcome. In addition, clinical performance regarding marginal discoloration, adaptation, secondary caries, and retention was evaluated as secondary outcomes using modified USPHS criteria. Outcomes were assessed at 24 h, 6, 12, and 18 months. The data was statistically analyzed using intention-to-treat analysis. Intergroup comparisons were performed using the Chi-Squared test with a significance level (p≤ 0.05), and intragroup comparisons were analyzed using Cochran’s Q test with a confidence level of 95% and a study power of 80%. Relative risk was used to assess clinical significance. The survival rate was analyzed using the Kaplan-Meier and Log-rank tests. The study was conducted following the CONSORT 2025 guidelines.ResultsBoth groups demonstrated similar performance in terms of postoperative sensitivity, retention, secondary caries, and marginal adaptation, as assessed using modified USPHS criteria. However, there was a significant increase in marginal discoloration within the phosphoric acid groups after 18 months. There was 50% less risk of sensitivity with nitric acid compared to phosphoric acid using the VAS scale (CI (0.2512 to 0.9953);p= 0.0485). The tested groups showed an equal survival rate (p= 0.3771).ConclusionCombining nitric acid with a mineral-enriched system is a promising approach for restoring cervical carious lesions.

title: Introducing flowable resin composite as a novel palatal dressing after free gingival graft harvesting: a randomized clinical trial
abstract: ObjectivesThis study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of using a flowable resin composite compared to periodontal pack in reducing postoperative morbidity after free gingival graft (FGG) harvesting.Materials and methodsIn this randomized controlled clinical trial, 34 patients requiring FGG were allocated into two equal groups. The intervention group received a flowable resin composite dressing over the palatal wound, while the control group received Coe-Pak. Postoperative pain was assessed using a Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) and mean analgesic consumption over 14 days. Secondary outcomes included wound size and color match of the healing site assessed at weeks 1, 2, 3, and 6.ResultsThe control group reported significantly higher VAS pain scores than the intervention group on days 1–4 and 10 (p< 0.05), and highly significant differences on days 5, 6, 8, and 9 (p< 0.001). Analgesic use decreased significantly in both groups (p< 0.001), with no intergroup differences. Wound size and color match improvements were comparable between groups.ConclusionThe application of flowable resin composite significantly reduces early postoperative pain following FGG harvesting without compromising healing outcomes. Its ease of application, patient comfort, and comparable clinical performance make it a promising alternative to traditional dressings. However, further investigations are warranted to confirm the biocompatibility of flowable resin composites and their impact on soft tissue healing.

title: Decoding dental images: a comprehensive review of fractal analysis
abstract: ObjectivesNew tools aid in the diagnosis of diseases and thus help in advancing patient care. “Fractal Analysis” is a versatile method of applying nontraditional mathematics to patterns that are beyond understanding with traditional Euclidean concepts. This analysis can be used on radiographic and non-radiographic images in dentistry. In this review we aim to identify the usefulness of fractal analysis in dentistry in radiographic images, its applications and future scope.Materials and MethodsArticles published between 1992 and 2024 were retrieved through an electronic search of Medline via PubMed, Scopus, and Google Scholar databases. The search, which was limited to articles published in English, aimed to identify relevant studies by employing the following keywords: “fractal analysis,” “dental radiographs,” “mandibular,” “panoramic radiographs,” and “radiography.” Ultimately, 76 articles that addressed the application of fractal analysis in dental radiographs were selected.ResultsFractal analysis can reveal alterations in bone and in images of morphologically altered tissue, however no set values exist which could be used as a standard for diagnosing various conditions.ConclusionFractal Analysis can potentially be used as an adjunct to diagnostic tests as it is shown to identify alterations in bony and trabeculae patterns.

title: Croeso i feddiant Caerdydd o'r myfyriwrBDJ!
abstract: Welcome to Cardiff's takeover ofBDJ Student!This edition centres on our themeEmpowerment in action: Overcoming challenges in dentistrya celebration of resilience, creativity and the determination to make positive change. Cardiff Dental School, since its founding in 1964, has grown into a vibrant hub of clinical excellence and research innovation. Our location in the capital means we serve a diverse patient base from across Wales, nestled between the hustle and bustle of the city and the South Wales Valleys.A dental degree can be demanding, and each stage of training comes with its obstacles. Whether it's mastering new clinical skills, juggling a busy social life alongside endless coursework, or raising your voice on important issues affecting our patients and communities, challenges are ever-present. In this issue, our contributors show how they've met those problems head-on, turning them into opportunities for growth and inspiration.Inside, you'll find heartfelt stories likeFrom Rejection to Resilience: My Path to Dentistry, alongside cutting-edge educational initiatives such asTalking Teeth. Our global perspective shines through with students' reflections on their experiences in Kathmandu, while pieces likeGive Yourself Some Curing Timeremind us all of the vital importance of wellbeing and balance. We also tackle hot topics in dentistry, including space replacement treatment modalities to the rising trend of vaping among young people.Bringing this edition together has been a reminder that empowerment doesn't always come from big moments - sometimes it's in the small acts: sharing knowledge, supporting a peer, or taking that first step towards a new goal. We hope the voices in these pages inspire you as much as they've inspired us. title: Talking Teeth: Promoting children's oral health and widening participation
abstract: ‘Talking Teeth' is delivered by a team of staff and student volunteers. The programme is designed to encourage students to undertake their social responsibility as oral healthcare professionals while being mindful of their clinical academic commitments. The activities are therefore undertaken outside of their clinical commitments. The programme appoints a new student lead every year and empowers them to initiate and lead activities with close support of the staff lead. It allows students to take on leadership roles and appreciate the value of effective team working.The aims of ‘Talking Teeth' include:1.Promotion of oral health of children and young people2.Increasing engagement of oral healthcare teams with the local community3.Promotion of equity, diversity and inclusivity by widening participation in dentistry.

title: From rejection to resilience: My path to dentistry
abstract: I fell in love with dentistry the moment I witnessed the care dentists provide and the significant impact they have on patients' lives. I envisioned myself that one day I would transform smiles and make a difference.With strong GCSEs and A-Levels, I applied to dental school, confident that I met all the necessary requirements to secure the place. However, despite receiving interview invitations, I was ultimately faced with rejections. It was the first significant failure I had ever faced, and the disappointment that followed left me struggling with self-doubt. I began to question not only my intelligence but also felt as though I had let my family down. Rather than allowing this setback to define my worth, I chose to redirect my path and pursue a BSc in Dental Hygiene at the University of Portsmouth, aiming to gain clinical insight into the field.

title: A welcome from  the editor
abstract: Hello, and welcome to the latest edition ofBDJ Student, this month brought to you by Cardiff Dental School.In the latest in our series of dental school takeovers, editors Dania Al-Zubaidy and Millicent Brodie Cooper expertly take the reins and bring you an array of insightful, interesting and must-read articles from Cardiff students.  I would like to thank the editors and the contributors for their hard work and excellent articles and wish them all the very best for the year ahead, wherever that may lie.On that note, I would also like to welcome everybody back after their summer break, new students settling into their first year and new members! We're delighted to have you, and as our motto says,BDJ Studentreally is ‘for students by students'. We would love to keep hearing from all students offering clinical tips and career insight to peers and friends alike.It's also my pleasure to welcome Hfsa Fahad to the role of student editor. Hfsa's already making an impression and connections, and I'm very much looking forward to reading what she has in store for us throughout her time in the role.Enjoy the issue, and from all of us at theBDJPortfolio, we wish you the very best for the forthcoming academic year. title: An overview of the Human Medicines Regulations and use by oral healthcare professionals
abstract: Utilising dental hygienist and dental therapists to their full scope of practice has proven beneficial for improving patients access to dental care.1The main barriers to access have been overcome via the implementation of Direct Access.2However, since dental hygienists and dental therapists cannot write a prescription, their access to commonly used prescription only medicines (POM) such as Duraphat varnish and local anaesthetics has been limited.Schedule 17 of the Human Medicines Regulation has now been adapted, including dental hygienists and dental therapists in the regulated list of roles that can use, sell, and supply POMs.3It is crucial that the individual ensures they have completed the relevant training and notified their employer and indemnity before practicing under Schedule 17.

title: Discussing the various space-replacement treatment modalities possible following extraction of an unrestorable upper central incisor
abstract: Insertion of an acrylic immediate partial denture following extraction will aid socket haemostasis, and serve as an aesthetic, space-maintaining, and functional interim replacement while a period of bony healing occurs over three-to-six-months.1Construction of a permanent replacement will be necessary if a removable partial denture (RPD) is selected as the definitive treatment modality, and a chairside or laboratory reline may also be required during the interim phase. This is to account for the hard and soft tissue remodelling processes that occur following tooth loss, resulting in a significant loss of alveolar ridge volume.2Although more costly than acrylic and subject to the patient's periodontal health, a cobalt-chrome RPD employs a rigid substructure to gain support from both the hard and soft tissues, utilising rest seats to transmit occlusal loads down the long axis of supporting teeth.3Cobalt-chrome RPDs may also incorporate a gingivally-free design to minimise plaque accumulation, with no element of the RPD crossing the interproximal gingival margin in accordance with Scandinavian design principles.4Had it not been deemed unrestorable, elective endodontic treatment of the upper central incisor and its maintenance as an overdenture abutment could also be considered to provide proprioception for increased biting forces, improved denture retention, and contribute to maintaining the alveolar bone.Learning how to function with an RPD for processes such as mastication and speech can take time to develop neuro-muscular control for. Concerns regarding denture retention coupled with the psychological acceptance of wearing an RPD may be challenging for the patient.5Furthermore, studies present a strong relationship between RPDs and both root caries and gingival recession associated with abutment teeth, regardless of adequate oral hygiene measures.6Patient factors, such as a high smile line, also increase the difficulty of achieving an aesthetic result. Retention using ball-ended cribs on maxillary first permanent molars can avoid visible clasping of abutment teeth, and the use of an open-faced, or ‘gum-fit', design will conceal the junction between labial flange and mucosa, provided no significant labial resorption has occurred.7

title: Irrigation: The most important stage of endodontic treatment? A discussion
abstract: Historically, the cornerstone of endodontic success has been the achievement of a tight seal to prevent reinfection. However, in recent years, increasing emphasis has been placed on the role of irrigation. Many contemporary research papers in the field of endodontics have focused on advancements in irrigation protocols, materials, and associated technologies.1This volume of research highlights the pivotal role of irrigation in the success of endodontic treatment.Success in root canal treatment depends on a combination of factors: mechanical preparation, disinfection, obturation, and coronal sealing. Although the importance of irrigation cannot be dismissed, whether it outweighs all other factors in determining success is debatable. This discussion will critically appraise the research and provide a perspective on whether irrigation can indeed be considered the most critical component of endodontic success.

title: Give yourself  some  curing time
abstract: Coming to terms with the workload that life as a dental student brings can be a challenge and remembering that you need to balance a personal life with this is even more demanding. Being efficient whilst also being effective is a skill that takes years to master, both academically and clinically. The pursuit of success can easily lead to non-stop work, making careful balance essential. Relentless scheduling often leads to burnout, which is why tools like to-do lists (Todoist), paper planners and simply knowing deadlines in advance help keep track; whether you prefer to meet or beat them. Intertwined with being an academic weapon, it's imperative to plan for some downtime, because sometimes it's good to be busy… doing nothing.Achieving good overall well-being helps in many areas; a state of being both healthy and happy. Stress can be a good motivating force, but when it crosses a certain threshold, it can become harmful to well-being. Developing self-awareness and recognising when stress shifts from being productive to detrimental is key to maintaining balance and preventing burnout. This idea is further explored later, focusing on accepting the journey of development and rewards of marginal gains. Understanding the benefits of self-care, mindfulness and resilience is essential for dental students to navigate the demands of training.1Prioritising these helps maintain optimal mental and physical well-being, while balancing sustainable habits fosters long-term success and professional growth.

title: Breaking free: Empowering youth to overcome vaping and nicotine addiction
abstract: While the long-term effects of vaping are still being studied, evidence suggests that the chemicals found in vape liquids may pose significant health risks. Most vape liquids contain nicotine, propylene glycol, vegetable glycerine, and various flavouring agents.2When heated, these substances form an aerosol mist which can be inhaled into the lungs for nicotine delivery.At high temperatures, propylene glycol and vegetable glycerine breaks down into formaldehyde and other carcinogenic aldehydes. These carcinogens increases the risk of lung damage and may contribute to respiratory illnesses and cardiovascular disease.2,3,4What's more, nicotine exposure during adolescence can interfere with brain development, potentially leading to cognitive impairments, reduced attention span, and alterations in working memory.5Studies have also shown that nicotine can reduce prefrontal cortex activation, which plays a crucial role in decision-making and impulse control.5

title: ‘I've found a real sense of purpose  in this work'
abstract: Rebekah Martindescribes the importance of educating children about oral health early in their lives, and her activities visiting local schools and nurseries. When I began my dental nursing journey in October 2020, one of the first things that truly surprised me was discovering how many patients either didn't brush their teeth at all or only brushed once a day. Having grown up with the routine of brushing twice daily, I had assumed it was the norm for everyone. It was a real eye-opener - and it made me realise just how much work there is to do in raising awareness about oral hygiene.This realisation was reinforced when I came across the findings from the 2022 National Dental Epidemiology Programme (NDEP) survey, which revealed that 29.3% of five-year-olds in England had enamel or dentine decay.1That's nearly one in three children starting school already experiencing tooth decay - something that is largely preventable with the right education and habits.It was then that I realised I wanted my role to go beyond the dental chair. I felt a real passion to help shape healthier habits from the very beginning - starting with children. Reaching them early, before poor routines take hold, gives us the best chance of setting them up for a lifetime of confident, healthy smiles.Since then, I've embraced every opportunity to promote oral health education. As a dental nurse in the East Midlands with Bupa Dental Care, and in my role as the Oral Health Education Representative for the British Association of Dental Nurses (BADN), I've found a real sense of purpose in this work. Educating children about how to care for their teeth isn't just a job - it's a passion. The earlier we start, the more natural these habits become, and the greater the long-term impact on their health and wellbeing. One of the most rewarding parts of my role is visiting local schools and nurseries to deliver fun, engaging oral health sessions. These visits are more than just educational - they're interactive experiences designed to make learning about teeth exciting and memorable.Before each visit, we coordinate with the school to understand the number of children we'll be speaking to and the preferred style of presentation. For younger children, we keep things short and sweet with group chats followed by hands-on activities. For older students, we often deliver assembly-style talks that allow us to reach a larger audience with age-appropriate messaging.We usually attend as a dentist-and-nurse team, and we always welcome extra hands from our practice to join in the fun! One recent visit took us to Busy Bees Nursery, where I was joined by Dr Humzah Jessa and Leah Blakeman, a soon-to-be-qualified dental nurse. We had the pleasure of speaking to two groups of children aged two to four.We began by introducing ourselves and explaining our roles in simple terms. Then came the fun part - talking about brushing teeth and healthy eating through games and activities. One of the children's favourites was our ‘thumbs up/thumbs down' food game, where they guessed whether different foods were good or bad for their teeth. Cheese sparked some debate, which gave us a great opportunity to explain its benefits.We wrapped up the visit by handing out toothbrushes, toothpaste, brushing charts, and stickers - leaving behind a room full of smilesAfter our group talk, we moved into activity stations. The most popular? The ‘Dress Like a Dentist/Dental Nurse' corner, where children donned gloves, masks, visors, and even used real dental tools like mirrors and suction tubes (safely, of course!). Other stations included:Toothpaste Matching Game (thanks to Twinkl)Toothbrush Line TracingPlaque Brushing Challenge - where children used toothbrushes to clean laminated ‘plaque-covered' teeth.We wrapped up the visit by handing out toothbrushes, toothpaste, brushing charts, and stickers - leaving behind a room full of smiles. Another recent visit took me and my fellow dental nurses, Laura Burd and Joanne Bagshaw, to a local primary school where we presented to a reception class. The children were full of energy and curiosity, and it was a joy to see how engaged they were throughout the session. We introduced ourselves, explained our roles, and then launched into a fun and interactive talk about brushing, healthy eating, and visiting the dentist. The teachers were incredibly supportive and commented on how valuable the session was - not just for the children, but for reinforcing oral health messages already being taught in class. It's always rewarding to hear that our visits are making a difference, and this one was no exception. Last year, I also had the pleasure of being invited to my children's primary school to take part in their first career fair morning. I eagerly accepted the invitation, as it was a wonderful opportunity to not only promote oral health but also to inspire young children to consider a career in dentistry. The career fair was a great success, and I am looking forward to attending again this July.I'd love to see oral health education become a standard part of the national curriculum. Many schools don't realise that local dental practices are eager to support them with visits and resources. Back in the surgery, I continue to champion oral health by providing young patients with brushing charts, toothbrushes, and timers to encourage good habits at home. Many children feel nervous about visiting the dentist, so we do our best to make each appointment as enjoyable and reassuring as possible. We guide them through every step, offering the comfort of sitting on a parent's knee or holding their hand - whatever helps them feel safe. It's especially rewarding to see children who've been coming since they were babies now hop confidently into the chair. It's a clear sign that we're no longer seen as so scary. I truly believe that when children learn positive habits early on, they're more likely to carry them throughout their lives.I'd love to see oral health education become a standard part of the national curriculum. Many schools don't realise that local dental practices are eager to support them with visits and resources. It's a part of my job I find incredibly fulfilling, and I'm always encouraging others to get involved.One great way to do that is through Dentaid's Bright Bites programme,2which I volunteer for. It's open to anyone passionate about making a difference in children's oral health - and I highly recommend signing up! Office for Health Improvement and Disparities. title: Empowering patients to take control of their oral health
abstract: A structured, whole-person approach is the best way to promote oral health to patients, saysCheryl Goodenough. Promoting oral health has always been a key part of my career in dental nursing over the past 25 years, but over time, I've realised that lasting change comes from a structured, whole-person approach. At my practice in Gloucestershire, we have integrated aspects of the British Society of Periodontology (BSP) guidelines1into our patient journey, ensuring prevention, risk management, and education are embedded into every appointment. Our goal is not just to treat periodontal disease, but to empower our patients to take control of their oral and general health. The approach gives us a clear framework to follow, allowing us to deliver high-quality, consistent care. In every appointment, whether it's an examination, hygiene visit, or a follow-up, with a team approach, we use this structure to guide conversations, build rapport, and deliver targeted oral health advice. Patients benefit from understanding where they are on their periodontal journey and what steps they need to take next take to improve their oral care.©Oleksandra Polishchuk/iStock/Getty Images Plus As a dental nurse who is oral health qualified, I am lucky enough to be given my own clinic within practice. These prescribed appointments from our clinicians are bespoke 40-minute slots which allow me to build trust with patients and explain things in a relatable way. Using the BSP model, we now ensure that every interaction reinforces the message of prevention and selfcare.For example, when discussing staging and grading of periodontal disease with the patient, we use visuals in the form of PowerPoint slides highlighting stages of gum disease using simplified terminology, to explain what their current diagnosis means and how lifestyle factors like smoking, diabetes, or oral hygiene influence outcomes. Patients often engage more when they understand how their personal risk factors link to their gum health. We also explain the long-term benefits of stabilisation and helping them see that regular visits and home care are not just routines, but part of a personalised health plan.With challenges like misinformation online and stretched resources, the need for strong, structured oral health promotion has never been greater. Successful implementation requires teamwork. At my practice our dentists, dental hygienists, and dental nurses all play a part in delivering consistent, evidence-based messages. Our nursing sessions encourage and demonstrate the use of interdental brushes, brushing techniques and follow up on lifestyle advice like smoking cessation, diabetes awareness, and connections to other oral health conditions, all tailored to the patient's needs. We also make sure patients understand their responsibility in maintaining gum health between visits. Our patients have achieved many positive results and their periodontal conditions have stabilised, making these appointments absolutely invaluable. The guidelines help us move away from one-size-fits-all advice. By combining staging and grading with age-appropriate education, we personalise our oral health messaging:Childrenlearn through interactions and visuals, focusing on brushing technique, disclosing to highlight plaque and sugar awarenessTeenagersbenefit from understanding how gum health affects appearance and confidenceAdultsare supported with habit change, diet, smoking, and oral hygiene routinesOlder adultsreceive guidance on dry mouth, medication interactions, and general mouth care.We also consider accessibility, adjusting our approach for patients with additional needs or neurodiversity. With challenges like misinformation online and stretched resources, the need for strong, structured oral health promotion has never been greater. As a practice we use this framework to benefit all our patients, and we would highly recommend dental practices utilise their oral health trained dental nurses to implement a similar programme. Our programme feedback has been nothing but positive from our patients and the results speak for themselves. We have even been lucky enough to win the Impact Award for this programme from the Society of British Dental Nurses. Outside of the practice, we continue to promote oral health messages through local school visits with the support of Dentaid, educating our younger generations. Our appointments have become opportunities to prevent, personalise, and empower. Oral health promotion isn't just about telling patients how to brush their teeth, it's about helping them understand their risk, make informed decisions, and take charge of their own health.By working as a team, supporting each patient's journey, and reaching out to them, we can reduce the burden of periodontal disease and improve overall wellbeing one conversation at a time. BDJ Teamwould like to congratulate Cheryl for running an amazing 100 km on  21 June (a Cotswold Way Ultra Challenge) and raising £795 for Young Tongues, a global support charity dedicated to individuals aged 18-64 who have been diagnosed with tongue cancer.https://www.youngtonguesglobal.com/ Author informationCheryl is a dental nurse and treatment coordinator at Woodcock Lane Dental Centre, the Health and Wellness Advisor for the Society of British Dental Nurses, and aBDJ Teamreader panellist. She has 25 years of experience in many areas of the dental nursing profession and holds post qualifications in dental radiography, oral health education, fluoride application, treatment coordination, and mental health at work first aid. She is currently completing Level 3 vocational qualification in Assessing. Outside work, she has a passion for running ultra marathons and raising money for charities close to her heart. title: ‘When you work as an oral health promoter, you are in the driving seat'
abstract: BDA Education'sAnne-Marie Moisleyinterviews Sheryll, the student who wanted ‘to know the science behind oral health education' and was determined to wear the BDA OHE badge, to ask about her journey and how she achieved her ‘dream to become an oral health promoter'.©Dmitry Volkov/iStock/Getty Images Plus The British Dental Association (BDA) offers a nationally recognised BDA Education Certificate in Oral Health Education (OHE), which qualifies individuals to work as an oral health educator within their practice. Sheryll John-Vidot is an oral health promoter (OHP) involved in a variety of operational aspects of an oral health promotion team for three London boroughs. Sheryll qualified with the BDA as an oral health educator in November 2024.Sheryll John-Vidot Tell us a little about your background and your route to becoming an OH promoter.The first seeds were sown at a young age. I was 12 when I sat in the dental chair looking at the orthodontist and dental nurse working together to fit my braces, listening to the radio and also having a laugh, and thought to myself, ‘this would be a nice place to work'.My assessor from the dental nursing course recorded me giving oral health advice to a patient and said I should become an oral health promotor. At the time, I didn't know what that was, so they explained that I would see my own patients and give them tailored advice. This sounded good and something I hoped to do in the future.Once I had qualified as a dental nurse,  I secured a job in a private practice in 2006.Keen to broaden my skill set, I then secured a job in what went on to be an award-winning private practice for children. Here I had a more vocal role in providing children's oral health advice to their guardians and learned a lot from the dentists I was working with. But I wanted more knowledge in this area.Whilst working at the children's practice, I completed the BDA Education Certificate in Dental Radiography, which I found daunting at first, but really enjoyed. I also qualified in fluoride application. These courses helped me to feel more involved in patients' care.Next, I joined special care dentistry in a hospital. I enjoyed my extended duties working in the community, visiting patients in their homes and going on domiciliary visits. But something was still missing. I regularly asked during my appraisals about joining the Oral Health Promotion Team. Then one day a job came up and I was appointed to the position. I was so thrilled!Is this role very different to dental nursing?Yes, as a dental nurse, you take the lead from the dentist, but when you work as an OHP, you are in the driving seat. For example, if I attend a play group to give advice, there is no receptionist; I need to make my own bookings and manage my own diary. I need to make a lesson plan and take the time to consider what I want my audience to take away from our interaction. Instead of a mirror, probe and tweezers, I may need giant teeth, a giant toothbrush and some leaflets. Planning my resources is important.What prompted you to complete the BDA OHE qualification?Though I have learnt so much from the dental professionals I have worked with over the years, I had always wanted to obtain a Certificate in Oral Health Education. I felt like I had the knowledge but wanted to know the science behind it. I had to do it - I owed it to myself, plus I wanted the OHE badge!My week is completely variable; it's exciting and never the same each day.Tell us about how the new supervised tooth brushing programme for nursery and reception pupils, that was launched in January 2025, has been received.The programme, in my opinion, has been very well received. The children enjoy brushing their teeth with their peers and doing it as part of the school day. Parents have commented that their children are more interested in brushing at home since the programme started. The staff tell me they are relieved that the programme is running as they are aware of the impact of child dental decay. It affects the whole family with missed workdays for parents and missed school for the child due to feeling unwell or being sent home due to pain and being unable to focus.Can you briefly describe a working week?My week is completely variable; it's exciting and never the same each day. One day I could be attending a meeting in a school to discuss the possibility of implementing supervised tooth brushing. The next I could be visiting parents/guardians and their children (with additional needs), to provide tailored 1 to 1 advice in the comfort of their own home. Or, I could be providing training to staff from nursery schools, creches or childminders looking to achieve one of the Healthy Early Years London (HEYL) awards. Or I may be working on resources, such as creating a PowerPoint presentation, or in a classroom with 30 children singing, ‘This is the way we brush our teeth'.Do you feel the OHE qualification has benefitted your role, how?Yes absolutely! I feel even more confident now as it has deepened my understanding of the science supporting oral health advice and widened my knowledge of oral health conditions.Knowledge is power, so empower yourself, and you never know when that OHE qualification may come in handy.Would you encourage or recommend our BDA OHE programme to a colleague?If I said ‘BDA' it would speak for itself!To a dental nurse I would say, go for it! Knowledge is power, so empower yourself, and you never know when that OHE qualification may come in handy.Don't be afraid and worry about how to fit everything in. The online aspect and flexibility of the programme was perfect and fitted so well around my young family and work commitments. I found I could study at 5 am and still have time to get my son ready for school.Dental nursing jobs come up all the time, however with Oral Health Educator/Promotion roles - you never know when the opportunity arises, so you need to be prepared and gain the BDA qualification.Is there one thing you would change about the OHE programme?It was brilliant, I enjoyed the course immensely, the modules were fun and easily accessible. I appreciated that I could study at any time of day or night. If I could change one thing, I would add an audio book, something that I could play to help me revise while I was doing something else like going for a walk.To find out more about the BDA's courses for dental care professionals (DCPs), visithttps://www.bda.org/learning/courses-for-dcps/. title: Reaching further with  oral health education
abstract: Harry Morrisexplores how forward-thinking oral healthcare teams are turning everyday care into meaningful education, and why this shift matters more than ever.©EMS UK One of the most important shifts in modern dentistry is the growing emphasis on education as an integral part of patient care. Oral healthcare teams are no longer focused solely on treatment delivery but increasingly see themselves as advocates for prevention, inclusion and long-term behaviour change. At EMS, we are proud to support practices across the UK and Ireland that are leading this transformation, finding creative, practical ways to build understanding and confidence at every stage of the patient journey. A common challenge in oral health promotion is helping people understand what they cannot see. Biofilm, the primary cause of both caries and periodontal disease, is invisible to the naked eye and often underestimated by patients. While dental professionals are familiar with its impact, many individuals assume that clean-looking teeth equate to good oral health.This is where visual learning becomes invaluable. Practices using disclosing agents, intraoral cameras and real-time demonstrations report greater engagement during hygiene appointments. The visualisation of biofilm often prompts questions, clarifies the importance of daily routines and helps reframe the patient's role in their own care. Education is not confined to the dental chair. Some practices have explored community-facing approaches such as Guided Biofilm Therapy (GBT) open days, informal events where members of the public are invited to receive hygiene advice, observe demonstrations or try disclosing tablets. These initiatives can create a low-pressure environment to introduce key oral health messages and engage individuals who may not routinely visit the dentist.One example took place in Brighton, where EMS partnered with Christina Chatfield's Dental Health Spa to host an open day in the school holidays dedicated to children's oral health. As part of the event, Swiss Dental Academy trainers delivered GBT to young patients in a calm, educational setting. The aim was to help children feel comfortable with hygiene care and introduce the concept of prevention in an accessible way.A different approach was taken at The Health Society in Mayfair, where Dr Victoria Sampson hosted a dedicated preventive open day for members of the consumer press. Held on a Saturday to maximise access, the event offered appointments focused on the GBT protocol and attracted health influencers with a combined audience of over 300,000. The team used the opportunity to highlight the science behind biofilm and the importance of preventive oral care, helping to extend key messages far beyond the surgery and into mainstream health conversations.Outreach can also take other forms, from participating in awareness events to supporting local health campaigns. These activities offer practices a route to connect with their wider communities and reflect a growing commitment within the profession to promote oral health beyond treatment alone. Inclusive education requires thoughtful communication. Many practices are now adapting their materials and clinical interactions to improve their support of patients with anxiety, neurodivergent needs or limited health literacy. This might involve simplified explanations, calm routines, or tailored appointment reminders that reduce stress and increase understanding.Education also continues long after the patient has left the surgery. Increasingly, practices are using digital platforms to reinforce preventive messages. Some share short videos on social media or in waiting rooms explaining how biofilm forms, how to brush effectively, or how oral health connects with general wellbeing. These messages are often most powerful when paired with the visuals and conversations patients experience during their hygiene appointments.When practices put education front and centre, they are contributing  to a wider culture of prevention, empathy and accessibility.Clinicians such as Laura Bailey are helping lead the way in this space. By using Instagram to share engaging, evidence-based oral health content with the public, she has built a growing following and created an accessible channel for prevention messaging. Her posts range from brushing technique tips to the science behind biofilm, helping patients understand the ‘why' behind professional guidance and reinforcing trust in the hygiene visit itself. Integrating education into daily dental workflows is not just beneficial, it is essential. Whether delivered chairside, online or out in the community, these messages help patients make informed decisions, form better habits and feel supported in their care. When practices put education front and centre, they are not only improving individual outcomes but also contributing to a wider culture of prevention, empathy and accessibility.To learn more about how the GBT approach can support prevention-led care and patient engagement, visitwww.ems-dental.comor contact your local GBT Expert. Author informationHarry Morris is General Manager of EMS UK, leading the British division of Electro Medical Systems (EMS), the Swiss innovator behind Guided Biofilm Therapy (GBT). Appointed in May 2025, Harry brings extensive experience in commercial strategy, clinical education, and operational delivery.Harry's journey with EMS began in 2018, when he joined as Area Sales Manager for the Midlands. In his first year, UK sales surged by 85% under his leadership, paving the way for EMS's national expansion. He later progressed to become Sales Manager for the UK & Ireland GBT division, where he played a key role in launching the UK subsidiary, scaling operations, and implementing training-led growth with GBT ambassadors.In his new executive role, Harry is focused on elevating the customer experience across EMS UK. He has introduced robust systems and processes to ensure every interaction - from initial consultation to after-sales care - is proactive, personalised, and aligned with EMS's values of clinical innovation and service excellence. title: Editor-in-Chief's letter
abstract: ‘Oral health must be considered in conjunction with general health'; ‘it's time to put the mouth back into the body...' - these are statements that are being quoted regularly nowadays by most stakeholders across the oral and dental health profession. The government's ten-year NHS health plan published just recently also highlights a positive shift away from ‘treating disease' to ‘preventing disease'. Myself and others in the profession have long been calling for this paradigm shift away from an essentially ‘national illness service' to a real ‘national health service'. A treatment-based healthcare service is not fundamentally sustainable long term, both economically or socio-ecologically. Attitudes across all oral health stakeholder groups need to change, from policy makers to funders, from clinicians to the public, from industry partners to regulators. Let‘s move away from the treatment question: "What is the matter with you?" to "What matters to you?" Prevention in all its forms needs to be incentivised by and to all stakeholder groups. Oral health prevention messaging needs to be consistent, engaging, supportive, deliverable and pragmatic for members of the public to appreciate its value. Let's not forget, 90% of prevention has to be effective with personal ‘at-home' care. It's a two-way facilitation process, between patients and the oral healthcare team. This is where the role of the oral healthcare team members in oral health education, facilitation, empowerment and promotion becomes critical. Positive messaging, personalised achievable goal setting and motivation to empower the patient and caregivers, as opposed to simply ‘educating/lecturing' them, is pivotal in the psychology of behaviour change. Our profession has not been all that successful in doing this to date. There is a real public need to value and appreciate the importance of preventing oral disease and its implications to general health. The excellent articles in this issue ofBDJ Teamoutline several aspects of the key roles different members of the oral healthcare team play in this regard and the importance of this aspect of oral healthcare delivery, using the best practice minimum intervention oral care (MIOC) framework to do this. title: Premium, easy to use brushes that don't hurt our environment
abstract: Severe periodontitis is the sixth most prevalent medical condition in the world1and is linked to significant medical conditions such as diabetes, cardiovascular disease, Alzheimer's and pregnancy related complications.2One in four dental implants is at risk of peri-implantitis.3The primary reason for such a high incidence of periodontal disease is that the majority of people do not clean their mouth well enough to prevent accumulation of dental plaque.4 The S3 guidelines3,5highlight the importance of daily oral care in the prevention and management of periodontal disease around teeth and implants. Individuals are advised to brush twice and use interdental brushes once daily. Other interdental cleaning aids are not as effective as interdental brushes in the removal of plaque6and are only advised where the smallest interdental brush will not fit. Many of the dental brushes currently on the market are not easy to use, especially by those lacking manual dexterity, and amount in significant plastic waste. With the understanding of the critical importance of daily use of various brushes and the hurdles most individuals face, Dr Dip Malde was inspired to launch The Teeth Keeper. Dip is a practising dentist whose clinical practice is limited to periodontology and implant dentistry. The Teeth Keeper offers The Interdental Brush in nine sizes and The Precision Brush. Their products are designed to make plaque removal easy for everyone. The aluminium handle offers a premium, ergonomic solution for effective daily plaque removal especially in the posterior areas of the mouth. The replacement of only the brush heads coupled with plastic free packaging means a significant reduction in plastic waste. The Teeth Keeper products are supplied exclusively to dental practices in the UK. More information on The Teeth  Keeper products can be found atwww.theteethkeeper.co.uk. title: Avoiding the pitfalls  with clear aligners
abstract: In the UK, 93% of adults feel that having a nice smile and straight teeth would improve their overall self-confidence.1It's no surprise, then, that practitioners want to offer their patients a range of orthodontic options, including clear aligner treatment (CAT).
